data.title: if statement without braces breaks indentation on many languages
Unable to run specs due to `Module did not self-register`
data.body:
Quite recently I started to see this error whenever I try to run tests for a package on my machine (both using `apm test` or inside Atom): 

```
"Error: Module did not self-register.
  at Error (native)
  at Module.load (/Users/cedric/github/atom/node_modules/coffee-script/lib/coffee-script/register.js:45:36)
  at Function.Module._load (module.js:311:12)
  at Module.require (module.js:363:17)
  at require (module.js:379:17)
  at bindings (/Users/cedric/github/atom/node_modules/pathwatcher/node_modules/bindings/bindings.js:76:44)
  at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/cedric/github/atom/node_modules/pathwatcher/lib/main.js:6:32)
  at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/cedric/github/atom/node_modules/pathwatcher/lib/main.js:207:4)
  at Module._compile (module.js:455:26)

  at Module.load (/Users/cedric/github/atom/node_modules/coffee-script/lib/coffee-script/register.js:45:36)

  at Function.Module._load (module.js:311:12)
  at Module.require (module.js:363:17)
  at require (module.js:379:17)
  at Atom.module.exports.Atom.initialize (/Users/cedric/github/atom/src/atom.coffee:135:14)
  at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/cedric/github/atom/spec/spec-helper.coffee:2:6)
  at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/cedric/github/atom/spec/spec-helper.coffee:1:1)
  at Module._compile (module.js:455:26)
  at Object.requireCoffeeScript [as .coffee] (/Users/cedric/github/atom/src/coffee-cache.coffee:34:10)
  at Module.load (/Users/cedric/github/atom/node_modules/coffee-script/lib/coffee-script/register.js:45:36)

  at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/cedric/github/atom/spec/spec-suite.coffee:1:1)
  at Module._compile (module.js:455:26)
  at Object.requireCoffeeScript [as .coffee] (/Users/cedric/github/atom/src/coffee-cache.coffee:34:10)
  at Module.load (/Users/cedric/github/atom/node_modules/coffee-script/lib/coffee-script/register.js:45:36)
  at Function.Module._load (module.js:311:12)
  at Module.require (module.js:363:17)
  at require (module.js:379:17)
  at module.exports.runSpecSuite (/Users/cedric/github/atom/spec/jasmine-helper.coffee:31:3)
  at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/cedric/github/atom/spec/spec-bootstrap.coffee:24:3)
  at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/cedric/github/atom/spec/spec-bootstrap.coffee:2:1)
  at Module._compile (module.js:455:26)
  at Object.requireCoffeeScript [as .coffee] (/Users/cedric/github/atom/src/coffee-cache.coffee:34:10)
  at Module.load (/Users/cedric/github/atom/node_modules/coffee-script/lib/coffee-script/register.js:45:36)
  at Function.Module._load (module.js:311:12)
  at Module.require (module.js:363:17)
  at require (module.js:379:17)
  at window.onload (file:///Users/cedric/github/atom/static/index.js:20:25)
", source: /Users/cedric/github/atom/spec/spec-bootstrap.coffee (27)
```

I had two packages that were marked as incompatibles, so I disabled them to see if it was something related to that, but it didn't change a thing. 

When running the tests on Travis there's no problem though.

data.title: Letters in Romanian keyboard are hijacked
data.body: I'm on Windows 7, using the Romanian (Programmers) keyboard arangement. Right-Alt + s is supposed to be ș (s with comma below), but in Atom it opens a Spec Suite window (which seems to be running some kind of tests). Maybe the issue is that you should differentiate between left and right Alt?

data.title: Trigger event at the end of window-bootstrap
data.body:
Eg: `atom.workspaceView.trigger('ready')`

Event name up for debate, but we do need an event that tells packages the window has actually been loaded in order to lazy load non pre-window code.

data.title: Add start/end timestamps for timecop/profiling
data.body:
Keep the old variables for backwards compatibility, but store the `Date.now()` timestamps in `[variable]Start` `[variable]End` for measured durations.

Adds:
- `atom.getLoadSettings().shellLoadTimeStart`
- `atom.getLoadSettings().shellLoadTimeEnd`
- `atom.loadTimeStart`
- `atom.loadTimeEnd`
- `Package.loadTimeStart`
- `Package.loadTimeEnd`
- `Package.activateTimeStart`
- `Package.activateTimeEnd`

With this I was able to generate a timeline graph that you might be interested in seeing.

![](http://i.imgur.com/2XRpfe5.png)

It confirmed what I suspected (that shellLoadTime + windowLoadTime != totalLoadTime).

There's still the overhead of actually getting to `src/browser/main.js` to map out though.

data.title: Editor throws error every time I hit "backspace"
data.body:
I'm running Atom on a Windows 7 machine in a non-system folder, and every time I hit backspace, I get:

```
ncaught Error: channel closed child_process.js:413
target.send child_process.js:413
module.exports.Task.send c:\Users\[...]\atom-windows\Atom\resources\app\src\task.js:97
module.exports.Task.start c:\Users\[...]\atom-windows\Atom\resources\app\src\task.js:87
module.exports.SpellCheckTask.start c:\Users\[...]\atom-windows\Atom\resources\app\node_modules\spell-chec…:31
module.exports.SpellCheckView.updateMisspellings c:\Users\[...]\atom-windows\Atom\resources\app\node_modules\spell-chec…:107
(anonymous function) c:\Users\[...]\atom-windows\Atom\resources\app\node_modules\spell-chec…:72
module.exports.Emitter.emit c:\Users\[...]\atom-windows\Atom\resources\app\node_modules\emissary\l…:118
(anonymous function)
```

I added the `[...]` in the addresses to protect my privacy. It goes to a subfolder of a folder on my desktop, if it's important.

Thanks.

data.title: Feature request for easier keybinding setup
data.body:
I'm currently experimenting with Atom keymaps, and I noticed that creating a keybinding seems somewhat complicated. I'd like to suggest a feature to make it simpler for most keymaps people will want to change. Take this list of bindings for example:

![screenshot 2014-08-18 17 24 35](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3695164/3958260/52451eb0-271e-11e4-9c27-3c17e7a06707.png)

If I'd like to change the keystroke for the first command (`autocomplete-plus:confirm`), I can just click on the `<li>`, and it will record my keystroke and override the package's default by inserting it into a keymap.cson. Something like this 
![screenshot 2014-08-18 17 28 17](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3695164/3958308/b295f4ce-271e-11e4-8960-9a7e2c48a1a7.png)
would show up and I could record my new keybinding.

It's just a thought, but I think that if it were implemented, many people would appreciate it and use it most of the time when altering keymaps in Atom.

data.title: scrollToBufferPosition is pretty much useless
data.body:
`scrollToBufferPosition` scrolls to anywhere it wants as long as the position specified is somewhere in the visible window.  It should scroll such that the position appears as the first line visible.  This killed a package I was working on.  

Even more importantly it makes any kind of synchronized scrolling impossible, which is a feature many users want and I was going to implement.

EDIT: It appears that the `center` option can be used to solve this problem.

data.title: Atom opening old version
data.body:
Sorry if this issue exists already, I searched but couldn't find anything.

**Issue:** Currently I have atom 0.123.0 installed on windows 8.  If I launch atom from the start menu, Help>Version shows 0.123.0.  If I launch atom by opening a file from Windows Explorer, Help>Version shows 0.115.0.  This may be the first version of atom I installed, but I think it was a few versions before that (110-113, I'd guess).
**Expected Behavior:** Regardless of how atom launches, the most current version should launch.
**Attempted Solutions:** I've tried telling windows to Open With atom from a few different locations, including the shim in /ProgramData/chocolatey/, and the shortcut on the start menu, which I know launches the right version.

Any assistance is appreciated.  I'm currently in between projects, so I am not writing much code, so I don't mind trying any suggestions, debug, etc, even if it kills things for a little bit.

data.title: Mobile (iOS or Android) port of Atom
data.body:
Since there are keyboards available for Android tablets, it makes a lot of sence to use a modern text editor on these devices. Since Atom is based on Chromium and web technologies, it should be possible to port it to Android.

I guess Atom could be a great first step to coding on Android devices.

data.title: Fix error when running `checkout-head-revision`
data.body:
I got the following error when running `checkout-head-revision`:

```
Uncaught TypeError: undefined is not a function /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/editor-component.js:804
addCommandListeners.editor:checkout-head-revision /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/editor-component.js:804
(anonymous function) /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/editor-component.js:840
jQuery.event.dispatch /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:4676
elemData.handle /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:4360
module.exports.KeymapManager.dispatchCommandEvent /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:400
module.exports.KeymapManager.handleKeyboardEvent /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:181
module.exports.WindowEventHandler.onKeydown
```

It looks like it was caused by a bad merge conflict resolution in 0eaec57.

Test Plan:

Built new Atom and pressed `cmd-alt-z` and didn't get an error.

Looked at a side-by-side diff to check for any other merge issues:

```
git difftool -t opendiff 32e59ce..32e59ce^ src/editor-component.coffee
```

data.title: Linux tests
data.body:
I've added :penguin: Linux support for `script/grunt test`... and _now_ I see that #2273 does the same thing! Whoops. I'll push this out anyway, I've made some different decisions and it might be interesting to pick and choose from each.

There are currently a small number of failures, which I've pasted into [a gist](https://gist.github.com/smashwilson/700a0e7368b85c450ec8). Attempting to build packages in parallel adds a few more.

Here are my system specs:

```
smash@winter ~/code/atom (linux-tests %=) $ uname -a
Linux winter 3.11.0-12-generic #19-Ubuntu SMP Wed Oct 9 16:20:46 UTC 2013 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
smash@winter ~/code/atom (linux-tests %=) $ cat /etc/lsb-release 
DISTRIB_ID=LinuxMint
DISTRIB_RELEASE=16
DISTRIB_CODENAME=petra
DISTRIB_DESCRIPTION="Linux Mint 16 Petra"
smash@winter ~/code/atom (linux-tests %=) $ cat /etc/os-release 
NAME="Ubuntu"
VERSION="13.10, Saucy Salamander"
ID=ubuntu
ID_LIKE=debian
PRETTY_NAME="Ubuntu 13.10"
VERSION_ID="13.10"
HOME_URL="http://www.ubuntu.com/"
SUPPORT_URL="http://help.ubuntu.com/"
BUG_REPORT_URL="http://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/"
```

data.title: Packages can't access original environment variables
data.body:
I use https://github.com/karan/atom-terminal to open terminals from atom
and I noticed some environment variables were set by atom (NODE_PATH and NODE_ENV) causing some difficulty when working with node scripts.

I hacked a solution locally by copying process.env variables except the 2 modified keys but a real solution would be to provide access to original environment (copy it at initialization and give possibility to require it in packages).

It should be before these lines:
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/atom.coffee#L150
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/atom.coffee#L153

Edit:
Atom-lint package also use a hack to access environment variables.

data.title: Inconsistency with editor:select-to-first-character-of-line key binding
data.body:
Like many developers, I constantly use **shift-cmd-left** and **shift-cmd-right** to select full lines. This command is designed to select up to the first and last character of the line. As of yesterday, it seems that it began selecting all the way to the beginning of the line (including indentation/tabs) in some very random cases.

In the screenshots attached, you'll notice that in 2 separate JSON files and 2 separate LESS files, the same command results in 1 correct result and 1 incorrect result. I am not noticing any patterns in the code or file formats that may hint at any weird problem. It feels as though it just picks some files to fail in and others to succeed in. It appears to work fine in every JS file, however.

Perhaps I am missing or forgetting something. But I thought I'd report this, as it slows me down, personally.. and I imagine it would for others.

![select-line-issues](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/498069/3945992/f9317aae-2659-11e4-9cc8-376f64aacc14.png)

data.title: Text cursor is lost when switching workspaces
data.body: The focus is maintained, but for some reason, I cannot see the text cursor when I switch namespaces, then go back to Atom. This means I have no idea where in the text I am...

data.title: Selected text is deselected when opening the contextual menu with CTRL-Click
data.body:
This issue was original opened as #2350 fixed with [pull request #2626](https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/2626) but that solution only fixed the issue if the contextual menu was opened using a mouse button other than mouse button one (e.g., opening it with mouse button 2). On OS X, contextual menus can also be opened by CTRL-Clicking, when the contextual menu is opened this way the selection is still lost.

Gif from #2350 illustrating the issue
![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/3053202/81614dea-e1a5-11e3-9baf-2c6caf2403a3.gif)

data.title: "Window" menu is pointless
data.body: Leave window management to the window manager. Move "Bring all windows to front" to the file menu or remove it altogether as it's a very niche command.

data.title: Delete does not work for files on NFS-shares
data.body:
I'm trying to remove files/dirs using sidebar, Atom asks if I want to move them to Trash and then nothing happens (files stay in the sidebar and on the disk).

This is valid only for files on a network partition, everything is ok with local ones

Version: 0.123
